solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(n^2 + 2^16 * n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(2^16 * n) ?
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
object Solution {
    def countTriplets(nums: Array[Int]): Int = {
        val counts = nums.flatMap(i => nums.map(j => i & j)).groupBy(identity).view.mapValues(_.length)
        nums.foldLeft(0)((res, i) => res + counts.filterKeys(x => (x & i) == 0).values.sum)
    }
}
```

solutions.title: linear-algebra-and-dimensional-reduction-commented-and-explained-o-n-time-and-space
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
To get this problem would really suck if you don't have linear algebra background. This is because you can take the problem, which naively runs in O(N^3), and reduce to O(N) if you are clever about it. To pull this off we need to realize that we can consider this problem as the determinant of the submatrices of a bit masked version of the binary values of our nums array. This is not a simple insight! I only came to it intuitively after setting up the problem in a different fashion and from there realized the striking symmetry of the problem; I leave in references to some others work with the venn diagram approach, who may or may not have realized the matrix space they were working in as a nod to other approaches as well. 

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
To set this up, start by first getting the binary form of all values in nums and storing them, along with the longest length you encounter on the way. 

From there, loop through your binary value strings and find the extension needed at each point as the difference of max length and this length. 
Append to extra bits this extension as another row in our overall extra bits matrix. 

At the end of this, we will have a matrix not well seen but implicitly defined as the length of our extra bits and the length of the first item in our extra bits array. 

We know make a cols to rows activated mapping where we will store which rows by index are activated by which columns in our extra bits matrix. We will find these in col major order so we progress in the fashion of linear algebra over the space, left to right and top to bottom. 

As we do so, if we find that we have a '1' in our extra bits for this row and this column, we are to add this row to our mapping for this column. 

Finally, we can set up a venn diagram intersection, as stated in other posts (this is really a listing of the determinant based findings of the sub matrices in our overall matrix of size row by row from above, but that's a separate post entirely) 

Set a count equal to 0. We are technically counting the over counting of the total size of our row by row matrix of extension of bits. 

Loop in col major order and as you do 
- If you have rows activated for this column 
    - we've definitely overcounted by any here on 3 times occassions 
    - Increment count by the number of rows cubed 
    - then for prior column in range of this column up to but not at 0 
        - consider each previous calculation we have made of the determinant (each prior entry in the venn diagram at prior column)
        - calculate the number of intersections of the previous entry with the current entry of cols to rows activated at col as the bitwise and operation 
        - if this intersection is not 0 
            - we also overcount here, we'll need to increase count 
            - but! this is a determinant, and submatrix considerations must come into play. This was a positive value if the prior column is even, otherwise it is a negative value. The value of the increment is as expected, the length of the intersection cubed for our 3 loop consideration normally 
            - Afterwards, whatever the intersection was, we will want to account for it on the next loop, so add it to the prior columns successor (prior column + 1) in the determinant calculations (venn diagram) 
    - after considering all prior columns, the determinant calculation at index 1 will need to also have the rows activated here appeneded as well since we considered them as well 

When the loop finishes, take the size of our matrix cubed and subtract from it the amount we overcount in the processing. This is our final answer. 

# Complexity
- Time complexity : O(N) 
    - Take O(N) to build all binary nums 
    - Take O(N) to build your extra bits 
    - The largest size possible for the matrix dimensions col major order outer loop must be max length - 0 -> aka max length
    - The max length considerable in the problem is 16, based on 2^16 
    - So the max we can have on our first extension is when it is 2^8
    - This would have us add 16 and 8 to get a size of 24 
    - Row unfortunately can run all the way to 1000, so we have at worst a matrix of size 1000 by 1000, aka O(N)  
    - Similarly we loop over cols, at worst 24 
        - and then do a sub loop of at worst 23 
            - but then have an inner loop of at worst N 
                - which sets our max at O(N) 
    - All told then, we have a run time of O(N) 

- Space complexity : O(N) 
    - Store N binary values
    - Store N extra bits 
    - Store 24 * N items in our cols activated 
    - Store 24 * N items in our venn diagram intersection perhaps 
    - All O(N)  


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def countTriplets(self, nums: 'List[int]') -> 'int' :
        # get binary string forms of the values 
        binary_values = [] 
        # and the maximal length possible 
        max_length = 0 
        # by looping over nums and building as you go 
        for num in nums : 
            binary_values.append(bin(num)[2:])
            max_length = max(max_length, len(binary_values[-1]))
        
        # figure out how many extra bits you'll need for a bit masked matrix 
        extra_bits = [] 
        # by looping over your binary values 
        for binary_value in binary_values : 
            # determining any needed extensions 
            extension = max_length - len(binary_value)
            # and extending it as needed  
            extra_bits.append('0'*extension + binary_value)
        
        # the length of the set up is your number of rows, and your initial is the number of cols 
        matrix_dimensions = [len(extra_bits), len(extra_bits[0])]
        # use this to determine mapping of column to rows activated in the matrix 
        cols_to_rows_activated = collections.defaultdict(set) 
        # by looping in col major order 
        for col in range(matrix_dimensions[1]) : 
            for row in range(matrix_dimensions[0]) :
                # and if you have a value there  
                if extra_bits[row][col] == "1" :
                    # updating appropriately  
                    cols_to_rows_activated[col].add(row)
        # we could do the above since all cells will go up to at least cols positioning 
        # as everything after that is longer overall. This lets us update without worries 
        # we now build a venn diagram intersectioni using some linear algebra in the work 
        venn_diagram_intersection = collections.defaultdict(list) 
        # where we are going to use determinant basically in our evaluation 
        count = 0 
        # col major order looping 
        for col in range(matrix_dimensions[1]) :
            # if we have a length here that is not 0 -> some rows activated  
            if len(cols_to_rows_activated[col]) != 0 : 
                # update count by this amount cubed 
                count += len(cols_to_rows_activated[col])**3
                # consider prior column entries up to the first but not including it  
                for prior_col in range(col, 0, -1) : 
                    # get the previous entries there at prior column 
                    for previous_entry in venn_diagram_intersection[prior_col] : 
                        # find value of intersection. If not zero 
                        intersection = previous_entry & cols_to_rows_activated[col]
                        if len(intersection) != 0 : 
                            # based on corresponding matrix position, you add or subtract 
                            # the appropriate valuation of the length of intersection cubed 
                            count += ((-1)**prior_col)*(len(intersection)) ** 3 
                            # and be sure to update the priors successor based on this  
                            venn_diagram_intersection[prior_col + 1].append(intersection)
                # after considering all prior columns, be sure to note that for the final 
                # entry we now must add the valuation of the cols to rows activated at col 
                venn_diagram_intersection[1].append(cols_to_rows_activated[col])
        # return you matrix dimensions of the row cubed - count of total 
        # this reduces us to the proper amount of values based on the cubing process 
        # where we would normally consider num for num in nums 3 separate times 
        return matrix_dimensions[0]**3 - count  
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
Store pairs of indices AND results and then compare each index value with stored values, storing should record number of repeats per AND value

# Approach
Nested loop everything with everything (quadratic), count how many times each and sum repeats, then run again loop for every value check if there is stored AND sum that combines to 0, if so increase result with number of repeats of that AND sum.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(N**2)

- Space complexity:
O(N)

# Code
```
from collections import defaultdict

class Solution:
    def countTriplets(self, A: List[int]) -> int:
        pairs, N = defaultdict(int), len(A)
        for i in range(N):
            for j in range(N):
                pairs[A[i]&A[j]] += 1
        return sum(pairs[k] if A[i] & k == 0 else 0 for k in pairs for i in range(N))

```

solutions.content:
class Solution(object):
    def countTriplets(self, nums):
        """
        :type nums: List[int]
        :rtype: int
        """
    
        self.zeroTable = [set() for i in range(16)] #Create a zeroTable for checking; zeroTable[i] is set include all the numbers has 0 in bit i

     
        self.biDict = {}
        nLen = len(nums)


        for n in range(nLen): #Step1. create the checking table
            for i in range(16):
                if((nums[n] & (1 << i)) == 0):
                    self.zeroTable[i].add(n)  
    
        results = 0 #Step 2. Go through all the possible combination of i,j.  Note: here can reduce some time, since (i, j) get same result as (j, i)

        for i in range(nLen):         
            for j in range(nLen):
             
                tmp = nums[i] & nums[j] #For each possible combination i,j, check the number of possible k by function self.findSet() 
                if(tmp == 0):   #If tmp is 0, then k can be any number
                    results += nLen 
                else:   #If tmp is not 0, then check how many k satisify
                    results += self.findSet(tmp) 
    
        return  results
    
    def findSet(self, num):   
        
        if(num in self.biDict): #hash mem
            return self.biDict[num]
        
        set1 = None
        for i in range(16): #Check the zero bit table, we want the intersections
            if((num & (1 << i)) != 0):
                if(set1 is None):
                   set1 = self.zeroTable[i]
                else:
                   set1 = set1 & self.zeroTable[i]
                
        if(set1 == None):
            self.biDict[num] = 0
            return 0
        
        self.biDict[num] = len(list(set1))
        return self.biDict[num]

```
def count_triplets(array)
  hash, total, n = {}, 0, (1<<16)
  array.repeated_permutation(2).each { |a, b| hash[a & b] ||= 0; hash[a & b]+=1 }
  array.each do |a|
    i = 0
    while i < n
      if a & i == 0
        total += hash[i].to_i
      else
	    # if a & i !=0, we could skip (a & i)-1
        i += (a & i) - 1
      end
      i += 1
    end
  end
  total
end
```
